courses.subject: SSPA
courses.title: Research Method in Sports Science and Physical Activity
courses.description: This course is designed as an introduction to basic research methods that are applicable to Sports Science and Physical Activity. It will enable students to acquire the necessary knowledge and skills to familiarize themselves with the topic and to conduct a research project in the discipline of Sports Science and Physical Activity. It is complementary to all advanced theoretical courses of the programme. Students will gain the competency to conduct a research project which may be submitted for publication in academic journals. E-learning platforms using the flipped classroom approach and blackboard are mandatory.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Education; MPhil Sports Sci & Phys Edu; MSc Sports Sci & Phy Activity and PhD Education
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to research in physical activity
• Using the literature and developing the problem
• Experimental and quasi-experimental research
• Ethical issues in research and scholarship
• Physical activity epidemiology research
• Survey and descriptive research
• Qualitative & Quantitative research
• The research proposal
• Results and discussion
• Ways of reporting research

courses.subject: SSPA
courses.title: Research Colloquia
courses.description: This course is designed to facilitate the development of graduate students’ research interests and ideas, and to build a community of collaborative research projects. The course provides a platform for teachers and graduate students to discuss and generate ideas on issues related to a variety of sports science and physical activity research topics. Students will present an in-depth study of a research topic of their choice, discuss issues among graduate students, teachers, and with invited experts in the field of research. Class formats include research presentation, discussion, debate and problem solving on selected issues. In the Research Colloquia, students are given an opportunity to integrate their knowledge, skills and practical experience gained in the program.

courses.subject: SSPA
courses.title: Quantitative and Qualitative Data Management & Analysis in Sports Science and Physical Activity
courses.description: The aim of this course is to equip students with the knowledge and skills to collect, input, manage, analyze, and present research data using quantitative and qualitative approaches. By providing students with key concepts and methods of a range of study designs and data analysis approaches, another important objective is to help students understand the methodological details provided in scientific publications. Common quantitative (e.g., analysis of variance, multiple regression approaches) and qualitative methods (e.g., inductive and deductive approaches) will be covered in this course. More advanced methods, such as systematic reviews and meta-analysis, will also be introduced. After completing the course, students will be able to complete data entry, cleaning/coding, select the appropriate analytical methods and conduct analyses independently. Students will also be equipped with the basic skills to present the analyzed data in different modes (e.g., scientific writing, poster presentation, and verbal presentations). Students are expected to possess basic knowledge in research methods within the field of sports science and physical activity, and basic computer skills, prior to taking this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Education; MPhil Sports Sci & Phys Edu; MSc Sports Sci & Phy Activity and PhD Education
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, students will be able to understand the basic concepts in statistics and qualitative data analysis. They will be able complete data entry, cleaning/coding, select the appropriate analytical methods and conduct analyses independently. Students will also be equipped with the basic skills to present the analyzed data in different modes (e.g., scientific writing, poster presentation, and verbal presentations).

courses.subject: SSPA
courses.title: Exercise: Physiology Benefits, Limit and Adaptation
courses.description: The aim of this course is to provide the students with up-to-date and research-based information for understanding the physiological aspects of exercise. This course will examine the current concepts of energy metabolism and other physiological responses to exercise and training. Emphasis will be placed on the application of such knowledge upon the improvement of exercise performance and upon the promotion of exercise. The students will be provided with hands-on experience of conducting laboratory work which examines the metabolic responses to exercise.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Education; MPhil Sports Sci & Phys Edu; MSc Sports Sci & Phy Activity and PhD Education
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will be able to:
• Understand the acute physiological changes that occur during exercise.
• Explain the metabolic responses involved in bioenergetics.
• Discuss the relationship between exercise intensity/duration and the physiological responses.
• Explain the influence of nutrition on human performance.
• Demonstrate the basic laboratory techniques on experimental testing.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to physiology and human performance
• Factors influencing exercise performance
• Bioenergetics and metabolism
• Energy metabolism and fatigue in working muscle
• Ergogenic aids and exercise performance
• Physiology of sedentary behavior
• Sport nutrition and exercise performance
• Thermoregulation and exercise performance
• Limitations to maximal oxygen uptake

courses.subject: SSPA
courses.title: Sports Nutrition for Health and Performance
courses.description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a sound understanding of the basic principles of human nutrition, and to build on this to cover in greater depth issues relating to the interactions between nutrition and exercise. The course will cover both the role of nutrition and exercise in a healthy lifestyle and nutrition for sports performance. Contents will include factors influencing sports performance, food intake and energy balance during rest, exercise and recovery; influence of nutrients on exercise performance; fluid balance and performance; protein nutrition and strength; and nutritional supplements. Practical work will be used to illustrate the topics covered in lectures, and written practical reports will be required.

courses.learning_outcomes:

• Participate in laboratory sessions and group tutorials to address the practical application of sports nutrition theory within the context of a research report.
• Further develop their laboratory skills in the collection of data for the write up of a scientific research report.
• Have the opportunity to discuss in detail the pertinent issues related to sports nutrition from a scientific research point of view and also have the ability to apply their knowledge to a real-world situation

courses.description: This course is intended to provide students with knowledge on health benefits of physical activity/inactivity from a behavioral epidemiological perspective. Students’ learning experience will be oriented on original research and significant authority reports. In addition, students will be enlightened in relation to assessment of lifestyle physical activity as well as the multilevel influencing factors of physical activity behaviors not only in a global but also in a local perspective. The practical part of this course enables students to get acquainted with the widely applied objective physical activity measurement monitors in the field. By applying the knowledge, students will be able to understand the significance and difficulties of promoting physical activity in our daily lives.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Early Childhood Education; Master of Education; MPhil Sports Sci & Phys Edu; MSc Sports Sci & Phy Activity and PhD Education
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will be able to:
• Understand the role of physical activity in promoting health, fitness and personal development in the community.
• Demonstrate an understanding of the relationship between health, fitness, and lifestyle factors in Hong Kong society.
• Understand the key elements of physical activity and how to assess lifestyle physical activity.
• Understand the foci for health and exercise promotion intervention and the strategies associated with each level of intervention.
• Elucidate key aspects of Hong Kong popular culture and lifestyle and identify the lifestyle factors determining the physical activity participation attitudes and profiles of the Hong Kong family and youth.
• Identify the potential contribution of the Hong Kong health, fitness, sport, recreation and physical education service delivery system to lifespan health, fitness and personal development.
• Design a community-based health, fitness and physical activity programme for the promotion of health skills in a range of Hong Kong environment.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to physical activity and health
• Theoretical foundations of physical activity
• Psychosocial and environmental correlates of physical activity: assessment and evidence
• Physical activity and health research: past and present
• The health consequence of physical inactivity
• Assessment of human movement and physical activity
• Physical activity in persons with a disability
• Walkability audit on CUHK campus
• Interventions on physical activity
• Barriers and facilitators of physical activity

courses.subject: SSPA
courses.title: Advances in Physical Fitness Assessment: Theory and Practice
courses.description: Keeping physically active and fit has been proven to be an effective strategy for improving one's quality of life, as well as preventing and treating chronic diseases. Physical fitness assessment is an indispensable part of an athletes training regimen. Hence, periodical assessment and evaluation of one's physical fitness level, becomes a fundamental part in maintaining and evaluating one's health. Knowledge, skill and the ability to conduct advanced fitness testing are essential requirements for most sports science research. This course is designed to enhance students' understanding of current trends in physical fitness evaluation, as well as to ascertain the skills and abilities needed to conduct advanced fitness testing. Subject matter related to theories, rationales, laboratory skills, and measurement techniques in current health and fitness evaluation will be discussed. This course is particularly useful for postgraduate students, as it will provide the fundamental and advanced knowledge and competency needed for their future health-related research projects. Lectures, group discussion, and laboratory experience are all expected.

courses.subject: SSPA
courses.title: Structural Biomechanics and Sports Injury
courses.description: This course examines the structure and function of the human body with a particular emphasis being provided on the aetiology of various common sporting injuries. Mechanical properties of connective tissue and muscle will be reviewed with a focus on: (1) tissue adaptation with physical activity and exercise, and (2) tissue failure in response to improper acute or chronic mechanical loading during sporting endeavors. Approaches that are used to examine the mechanisms of various sporting injuries will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Education; MPhil Sports Sci & Phys Edu; MSc Sports Sci & Phy Activity and PhD Education
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, students will be able to:
• Identify the structure and function of the human body
• Understand the mechanical properties of human biological tissue
• Understand how tissues adapt to loading
• Understand the pathophysiology of injury
• Understand the mechanism of selected common sports injuries.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Structure of the human body
• Mechanical behaviour of biological tissues
• Tissue adaptation and pathophysiology of injury
• Mechanisms of acute sporting injuries

courses.subject: SSPA
courses.title: Sports Injury and Rehabilitation
courses.description: This course aims to help students acquire knowledge of sports injury and rehabilitation; as well as basic practical skills in assessing, managing and preventing common musculoskeletal injuries associated with sports and exercise participation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Education; MPhil Sports Sci & Phys Edu; MSc Sports Sci & Phy Activity and PhD Education
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction of human musculoskeletal system: anatomical structure (skeletal system, joint classification, muscular system and surface marking) and biomechanics (anatomical position, anatomical planes & axes, joint movement, classification of levers, muscle contraction and movement analysis)

• Introduction to sports injury: incidence & prevalence, classification and aetiology of common sports injury, intrinsic vs extrinsic risk factor, prevention of sports injury and 3 stages of body reaction after sports injury

• Assessment and management of acute/chronic sports injuries: definition of acute & chronic sports injury, difference between signs & symptoms, “SOAP” principle

• Physical modalities of sports medicine: hot and cold, ultrasound, electrical stimulation, diathermy, low level laser therapy, magnetic field, anodyne therapy and extracorporeal shock wave therapy

• Assessing and managing upper limb injuries: shoulder fracture, anterior shoulder dislocation, anterior shoulder pain, shoulder impingement, lateral epicondylitis, medial epicondylitis, carpal tunnel syndrome and De Quervain’s disease

• Assessing and managing lower limb injuries: knee injury (ACL sprain, meniscus tear), ankle injury (lateral ligament sprain, muscle strain, tendon strain) and plantar fasciitis

• Assessing and managing back injuries: muscle and ligament strain, intervertebral disc protrusion (PID), intervertebral disc degeneration, spondylosis, spondylolisthesis, radiculopathy and myelopathy

• Introduction to sports massage & taping demonstration: mechanical, physiological and psychological effect of sports massage, different massage technique, lubricant benefit, elastic vs inelastic bandage taping application

courses.subject: SSPA
courses.title: Exercise Prescription for General and Special Populations
courses.description: Effective exercise prescriptions are an essential part of improving one's physical fitness and overall health. However, in order to provide an effective exercise program, exercise prescriptions must be individualized and specific to the participant's unique health conditions. As chronic illnesses, such as coronary heart disease, diabetes, hypertension, obesity, and lower-back disorder, become increasingly prevalent in modern urban settings, exercise prescriptions for the general population should be modified in order to cater to the specific medical indications of specific populations. Given that a regular exercise training program is recognized as good preventative medicine for chronic diseases, this course is designed to introduce information about specialized exercise prescription to meet the needs of general citizens and people with particular medical conditions. Students will be expected to become familiar with exercise prescriptions for general healthy populations and to use this knowledge to design exercise programs for targeted populations with specific chronic diseases.

• Principles and guidelines of prescribing exercise training program for hypertensive participants.

courses.subject: SSPA
courses.title: Sports, Pedagogy, and Technology
courses.description: The implementation of digital solutions in physical education embraces the basic fundamentals present in various aspects of modern education reform. This undertaking entails using technology to empower students and restructuring the learning process to enhance student engagement. Wearable technology, such as bracelets, adds a visual element to physical activities, thereby providing students with a digital representation of their activity levels. Furthermore, access to online resources enables physical educators to substantially expand what constitutes physical education. Numerous online instructional materials are available for different types of sports and physical activities that can be implemented in class, thereby providing students with a break from the norm. However, digital solutions go beyond merely enhancing the levels of student engagement and altering the curriculum by facilitating the extension of the educators’ influence outside the gymnasium and into the classroom. This course aims to explore and conduct experiment on the benefits and limitations of using technology as a pedagogical tool to conduct sports classes and physical activity sessions in contemporary society.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Early Childhood Education; Master of Education; MPhil Sports Sci & Phys Edu; MSc Sports Sci & Phy Activity and PhD Education
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, the students will be able to:
• identify the unique physical, social, or emotional needs that students face in sports and physical education;
• select and adopt an appropriate teaching or learning approach to accomplish specific assignments; and
• plan, implement, and evaluate an effective sports and physical activity program that is relevant to the needs and interests of students through a wide range of digital technology.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Understanding modern education reform and the role of technology in sports pedagogy
• Understanding learning and the learner
• What is quality physical education
• Curriculum models and teaching (coaching) philosophies and theories
• Understanding problem-based learning approach
• Individualized education programs
• Observation and analysis of instruction
• The Laban framework and fundamental movement learning through information technology
• Principles of sports training
• Task presentation, task Design & interactive teaching (coaching) approach
• Evaluation of Instruction - ASUOI
• Use of easy sport equipment and technology
• Principles of excellent teaching (coaching)

courses.subject: SSPA
courses.title: Information Technology in Sports Science and Physical Activity
courses.description: With the rapid development of global economies and technology, modern information technology has been entering the field of sports and physical activity. At present, within international and domestic sports organizations and management structures, supporting athletes training through the use of sports specific equipment, research and development facilities, sports information networks and sports utility software applications have become commonplace and indispensable. This course will examine the professional needs of practitioners involved in using digital technologies and their applications within the sport, exercise and health contexts. A key element of this course will be to develop a deeper understanding of recent emerging technologies that can aid with improving health from clinical devices to active lifestyle aids, how they are developed, how they can be used and how to utilise them in research and practice. Maximising the usage of IT for the advancements of various disciplines within the Sports Science sector will be involved in this course, investigating issues such as Motion Analysis of Human Movement, Sports Biomechanics and the use of Big Data metrics in assessing performance, both during competition and in training. The use of biomedical software in monitoring every movement in an athlete’s or individual’s kinetic chain - their muscles and joints, so as to fine-tune technique for performance/health/safety enhancement will also be examined.

• To produce a computer model that applies to a specific area of sport, exercise and health

• Entrepreneurial skills in IT and sports science

courses.subject: SSPA
courses.title: Professional Attachment
courses.description: The course of Professional Attachment is designed to exposure students to their professional role by completing hours of field experience and a specialized project in the actual setting of sports science industry and physical activity. Such experience is important for clarifying and broadening career goals. Through practical attachment students would be provided opportunity to apply what the students learned from the programme into a real industry setting; to extend and deepen the knowledge gained from the programme; to conduct critical analysis, synthesis, and evaluation of knowledge; and to develop skills and values that acquired both in the classroom and the practicum. The essence of the course is to put theory into practice. Due to the nature of application students are required to complete at least 12 credits of course work. Students enrolled in the attachment will continue their other course works in the regular terms, and could simultaneously engage in practical attachment at any time during the course of the MSc study, with mutual agreement between the course supervisor and the field tutor. Opportunity and selection of the interested industry can be initiated by the students and/or recommended by the course supervisor. Students should engage in not less than 100 hours in field placement to be agreed upon by your supervisor and field tutor. During the attachment period students are required to conduct a specialize projects and submit a project report at the end for grading purpose. Performance observation report from field tutor is also an integral part of the course assessment. Students must have obtained written approval from the Programme Director at least one term in advance before being accepted to the course.

courses.title: Guided Studies
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to allow the students to pursue advanced guided individual study in selected areas of Sports Science and Physical Activity. It will provide the opportunity for students to review the literature of their fields of interest and to prepare for the writing of their Project proposals. Examples are topics within the areas of exercise promotion, health related fitness, psycho-social application in sports and physical activity, physical activity measurement and evaluation, surveillance, sports training and coaching, administration, physical education as well as health and wellness education, etc. A student is expected to read according to a reading list prescribed or approved by the supervisors and to confer regularly with the supervisor. Assessment is based on the completion of reading and course requirements.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Sports Sci & Phy Activity
courses.course_syllabus: A variety of teaching methods will be used to facilitate students to better understand relevant theories and achieve the learn outcomes. Students are required to search the literature in the selected topic and analyze the findings of previous studies. They are also required to report to the supervisor about their study process face-to-face at different time points during the whole courses. A final report is required to assess the learning outcome.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcome to express feedback on course contents and learning experience via e-mail to the course instructor anytime during the course. A standardized course evaluation form will be provided at the end of the course for students to provide feedback.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline.

courses.subject: SSPA
courses.title: Research Project
courses.description: The Research Project aims to develop the student's ability to conduct independent research in the area of Sports Science and Physical Activity. It represents a step beyond the tutor directed Research Colloquia and Guided Study conducted in previous course. The Project will be expected to be an original research within the student's area of interest. Any relevant topic may be the subject of research, subject only to the agreement of the course committee, the availability of the necessary facilities, and the identification of a suitable supervisor. The Project must address a clearly identified problem and show evidence of familiarity with relevant literature, an appropriate experimental design and methodology, and a satisfactory interpretation of the results. At the conclusion of this course, students should be able to: 1) plan a research project; 2) conduct research in a professional and ethical manner; 3) present research effectively in written form; and 4) demonstrate in-depth knowledge of a relevant area. (Part-time students who obtain an overall GPA of 3.0 or above in their first year of attendance are eligible to take the course).
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Sports Sci & Phy Activity
courses.course_syllabus: Student will meet with the supervisor 3-4 times during the research period to discuss his/her research project and progress of his/her work. In addition, further discussion and communication will be conducting through emails and/or other electronic means. Students are also welcomed to make appointments with the supervisor whenever necessary.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcome to express feedback on course contents and learning experience via e-mail to the course instructors at any time during the course. A standardized course evaluation form will be provided at the end of the course for students to provide feedback.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline.
courses.recommended_readings:
• Baumgartner T.A. & Hensley L.D. (2006) Conducting and Reading Research in Health and Human Performance (4th ed.). Boston: McGraw-Hill.
• Bell, J. (2014). Doing Your Research Project: A guide for first-time researchers. McGraw-Hill Education (UK).
• Berg, K.E. and Latin, R.W. (2008) Essentials of Modern Research Methods in Health, Physical Education and Recreation (3rd ed.). Lippincott Williams & Wilkins.
• Gratton, C., & Jones, I. (2010) Research Methods for Sport Studies (2nd ed.). London: Routledge.
• Tanaka, H., & Seals, D. R. (2000) Manuscript Peer Review: A Helpful Checklist for Students and Novice Referees. Advances in Physiology Education, 23: 52–58.
